title: 114_hr2999
content: The "Fair VA Accountability Act" allows for the suspension and removal of Department of Veterans Affairs employees for performance or misconduct that poses a threat to public health or safety. The "Fair VA Accountability Act" amends Chapter 7 of title 38, United States Code, to allow the Secretary to suspend and remove VA employees for performance or misconduct threatening public health or safety. The "Fair VA Accountability Act" allows for the suspension and removal of VA employees for performance or misconduct threatening public health or safety. Suspended employees are entitled to specific procedures including written charges, an opportunity to respond, a hearing, review by the Secretary, and a written decision. This authority is in addition to other disciplinary rules. The "Fair VA Accountability Act" allows for suspension or removal of VA employees for performance or misconduct. Employees subject to suspension or removal may receive back pay if deemed a prohibited personnel practice. The term 'employee' refers to any individual within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Fair VA Accountability Act" allows for suspension or removal of VA employees for performance or misconduct. An employee is defined as an individual within the Department of Veterans Affairs under a permanent or indefinite appointment, not serving a probationary or trial period. The "Fair VA Accountability Act" allows for suspension or removal of VA employees for performance or misconduct that poses a threat to public health or safety. A report on suspensions and removals must be submitted by the Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within one year of the Act's enactment. The report on suspensions and removals of VA employees under the "Fair VA Accountability Act" must include the number of suspensions and removals, reasons for the actions, and details on employees who filed complaints related to prohibited personnel practices. The report on suspensions and removals of VA employees under the "Fair VA Accountability Act" must include the number of actions taken, reasons for the actions, and details on complaints related to prohibited personnel practices. This report should also cover the number of retaliatory actions against whistleblowers, suspensions or removals related to complaints about patient safety, and any recommendations by the Inspector General to enhance the authority for such actions. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON FORMER EMPLOYEE'S ACCEPTANCE OF COMPENSATION FROM CONTRACTOR. Section 717 prohibits former senior executive employees of the Department from accepting compensation from contractors for one year after leaving their position. Covered contractors are those with contracts with the Department, including subcontractors. The term 'senior executive position' is defined in section 713(g) of this title. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. SEC. 4 prohibits certain former employees from accepting compensation from Department contractors. It also limits contracting with entities employing recently separated Department employees. Limitation on contracting with entities employing certain recently separated Department employees: The Secretary may not contract with entities employing individuals prohibited from accepting compensation from contractors. Entities must certify they do not employ such individuals before entering into a contract. The Secretary is restricted from contracting with entities that employ individuals prohibited from receiving compensation from contractors. Entities must certify they do not employ such individuals before entering into a contract. Additionally, the definition of 'position' is provided in section 713(g)(3) of the title. A new item is added to the table of sections after section 8128 in the chapter. SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON ADMINISTRATIVE LEAVE FOR EMPLOYEES WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. Section 719 of Title 38, United States Code, limits administrative leave for employees within the Department of Veterans Affairs to 14 days in a 365-day period, with the possibility of extension upon submission of a detailed explanation to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary must provide a detailed explanation for placing employees on administrative leave or non-duty status without charge to leave, including the individual's name, location, and job title. This applies to employees under investigation for disciplinary action or facing proposed disciplinary action. The report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs every quarter. The Secretary must report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs the names of employees placed on administrative leave for more than 7 days, including their position, the number of days on leave, and the reason. This requirement applies to any removal or transfer actions starting from the enactment date. The report required under section 719(b) of the title shall apply starting in the quarter after 6 months from the enactment date. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 7. "Administrative leave limitation and report required after 6 months from enactment date."
